Karl Marx lived from 1818 to 1883, he developed his ideas during the mid-19th century. The Frankfurt School, which began in the 1920s, was developed about 40 years after Marx's death.

The Frankfurt School was considered radical for its time, even though Marxism had already shown that inequalities come from structures of power, because they added a new layer of analysis to the understanding of society. They emphasized the need to critically examine and challenge the societal structures of power and domination, which was not a common perspective at the time. They also emphasized the need for self-reflection and self-criticism, and the idea that individuals had the power to change society. They sought to understand how individuals internalize the dominant ideologies and how these ideologies can be challenged. They also sought to understand how individuals may resist oppression and work towards social change.

Foucault, on the other hand, defined power as a set of relations that exist between individuals, groups, and institutions. He argues that power is not held by one single group or individual, but is instead pervasive and operates throughout society. He also argues that power is not just repressive, it is also productive, it creates new forms of knowledge and ways of understanding the world, it shapes our desires and beliefs, and it is not just negative but also positive. Power is not just something that is held by those in positions of authority, but is also present in the everyday interactions and relations. It's a force that shapes our behaviors, beliefs, and desires, and not just something that is held by those in positions of authority.

Karl Marx and his ideas were certainly an important influence on the Frankfurt School. The founders of the Frankfurt School, Carl Grünberg and Felix Weil, were inspired by the Marxist tradition and wanted to create a research center that would apply Marxist theory to the study of contemporary society. They sought to understand how capitalist societies produce and maintain inequality and oppression and how traditional forms of Marxism were no longer sufficient in understanding the complexities of capitalist societies. Therefore, they developed a more interdisciplinary approach that included psychology, sociology, philosophy, and other fields in their analysis and added a greater emphasis on the role of culture and ideology in shaping society, and the ways in which individuals internalize and resist these ideologies.

In summary, Karl Marx and his ideas were an important influence on the Frankfurt School, but the Frankfurt School expanded on these ideas by adding a more interdisciplinary approach and emphasizing the role of culture and ideology in shaping society, and the ways in which individuals internalize and resist these ideologies.

Carl Grünberg and Felix Weil, the two founders of the Frankfurt School, were both important figures in their own right. Carl Grünberg was a philosopher and legal scholar and was the first director of the Institute for Social Research, the organization that later became known as the Frankfurt School. He was also a professor of law at the University of Frankfurt and was active in the workers' movement. Felix Weil was a young Marxist philosopher and social scientist, who provided the financial support to establish the Institute for Social Research.

Many of the students and scholars associated with the Frankfurt School went on to become influential figures in their own right. Some of the most well-known members of the Frankfurt School include:

* Max Horkheimer, who served as the director of the Institute for Social Research and was an important figure in the development of critical theory.
* Theodor Adorno, who was a philosopher, sociologist, and musicologist, and one of the most important figures in the Frankfurt School.
* Erich Fromm, a psychoanalyst, and social philosopher, who wrote "The Art of Loving" among other books.
* Herbert Marcuse, a philosopher, political theorist, and sociologist, who became famous during the 1960s for his critical analysis of contemporary society and his critiques of technology and consumer culture.
* Jürgen Habermas, a philosopher, sociologist, and political theorist, who is known for his work on communicative action and the public sphere.

In summary, Carl Grünberg and Felix Weil, the two founders of the Frankfurt School, were important figures in their own right, but many of the students and scholars associated with the Frankfurt School went on to become influential figures in their own right, with some of the most well-known members of the Frankfurt School include Max Horkheimer, Theodor Adorno, Erich Fromm, Herbert Marcuse, Jürgen Habermas among others.

The Frankfurt School existed during World War II, and many of its members were forced to flee Germany because of their Jewish heritage and their opposition to the Nazi regime. Some members, such as Max Horkheimer, Theodor Adorno, and Erich Fromm, were able to flee to the United States, where they continued their work and their critiques of capitalist societies. Others, such as Herbert Marcuse, were able to emigrate to other countries.

During World War II, the Frankfurt School scholars had a complex relationship with the Nazi regime, they were deeply critical of the ideology and the tactics of the Nazi regime, but they also recognized that the rise of fascism was rooted in the failure of liberal democracy and the economic crisis of the 1930s. They saw the Nazi regime as a reaction to the failures of capitalist societies and the weakness of the working-class movement.

Jürgen Habermas, one of the most famous student of the Frankfurt School, was not yet born during WWII, he was born in 1929. He is considered one of the most important German philosophers of the 20th century, he continued the Frankfurt School tradition of critical theory and developed his own ideas on communicative action and the public sphere. He is still alive and active, though retired, and continues to write and publish.
